body:
The problem is most of my interests depend on actually producing something, and I'm missing out on half the fun which is the result. This isn't someone else's rope, they were my interests from the beginning. They just happen to be very similar to sfrohne's. I have ASD which may be partially why I don't align with my biologically determined talents, as the rest of my family is perfectly content with it. I would think that normally you would be driven to do what you're made for, that only makes sense. But I'm stuck either trying to be someone I'm not and failing, or being whatever it is that I am and hating it.

Also you're thinking too recent in terms of lineage. You aren't made for a specific thing, you adapt to certain categories, and most of it would go back to ancient times; just because your family chose less skilled careers recently doesn't mean it was always so, as talented and smart people can do unskilled tasks but not the other way around. In ancient times, some people are servants, others are kings, others are generals, others are businessmen, etc. and they adapted to the talents for their skillset. Generally men were more labor and rationally oriented as well while women got better at creative abilities and more naturally intelligent, and this is also reflected in modern days. Unfortunately genetics are not fair, they're strictly utilitarian, and if you don't like what you're built for you're in trouble. Some types of people (like laborers or nonskilled servants) didn't really need any talents while others (like the elite and high class people) needed every talent they could get.

parent.body:
You seem to be towing someone else's rope. I wanted to be a pilot most of my life, but my mom always said I was too against the grain and would be a better investigator. I disagreed, I had zero interest in it. But, flying is expensive as fuck. Research is often free. I dabbled in a bit just for fun, and once I discovered I had a knack for it, it became more interesting. I was once in a training class for work and was classified as "independent thinker" in which I didn't give a shit what the mainstream says, I arrived at my own conclusions based on my own research. They said that's actually rare, but "many of life's greatest leaders belonged to this group". 

Lineage doesn't mean shit when you beat your own path. My ancestors were drivers, loggers, general maintenance, etc. But, that was then and this is now, the circumstances change. You seem like you're trying to be something you're not. I was a musician once, in a band that kinda sucked. But, I didn't give a shit because it was fun. I didn't get discouraged just because others did better. I embraced competition, it helped shape and build my own style. 

You have skills you aren't even aware of yet.

body: I think you're confusing talent and skill. Talent is the natural ability you have and what your max potential is, ie what you're *capable* of achieving. Skill is what you actually *do* achieve. Typically women have more of the former but little of the latter, however this is important because when you do get an ambitious woman she will have both. You also seem to think people are either black or white, that superior in one way means superior in every way, but that is not so. Men are clearly superior in athletics for example, and leadership, and being rational and well-grounded, and ambition and toughness (both mental and physical). However they are also inferior with regards to intelligence and creating things. The reverse is true for women.

body:
> The Word was written by the Holy Spirit acting within the authors, just as the Holy Spirit acted within those who perpetuated the text.

Yes but those people are not perfect. By that logic there would never be any arguments among believers. Zero. Because they would all agree 100% and never get anything wrong.

> God doesn't tell us that he is real and therefore the Bible is perfect. No. God says, if you think the Bible is perfect, then you must know that I am real.

This requires you to start with the bible which doesn't work unless you were raised in that tradition. But in the bible people knew he was real because it was self evident that it is the truth, whether they acknowledged it or not. Plenty of outsiders approached likely not knowing a word of scripture, and yet many of them had even greater faith. On top of that the bible has only existed since 382 AD, and it was not until very recently that the masses had access to it.

> What are the contradictions you are talking about in Genesis?

Genesis 1 tells the story of the 7 day creation that we are all familiar with. Genesis 2 is another version of the story, but in this one Adam is created first after the land and waters, and everything and everyone else is created for him and after him. In many ways this is the opposite of the previous one. Some people try to explain this away by saying it's "pluperfect" so it could mean what *had been* made, but lets be honest that makes no sense with its sentence structure. It's clearly two separate stories too, as the beginning of the second one has the header "An account of the creation of the heavens and the earth" even though that just happened in Genesis 1, and the writing styles are wildly different, you can tell even in a translation. I think the logical conclusion is that there were 2 differing versions of the creation account, and both were put in the collection of these stories now known as Genesis. This is also evident because otherwise scribes would've tried to harmonize it, and the whole book does not have any consistent theme really, it's a bunch of brief texts about the origin of Israel and Judah put together and this is obvious when reading it as a whole.

body: Two problems with that. One, if it's not my preferred category then what the fuck is even the point? Two, they all fail me. I impress most people currently but that's just because they've never done anything in their life. Every single thing I've ever done, I learn some information but make little progress anywhere. And that's just how it is, I think it's possible to be talented in one area but usually you're just either smart or you're not, creative or you're not, good at socializing or you're not, etc. People like sfrohne immediately excel to impossible levels in every aspect and others like me are stuck at a mediocre level in everything. Genetics isn't worried about being fair, it's worried about what roles in society your ancestors worked and if yours didn't need as many capabilities to accomplish then tough luck, that's what you're stuck with. In my case, I'm guessing most of the men in my lineage were laborers or servants, or something that doesn't need any sophisticated ability to do, just day in and day out, repeat the same process. They talk or watch the boring tv or sleep and that's about it, and on special occasions do little more than have a beer and chit chat about pointless topics. Basically Homer Simpson. And there's nothing wrong with that, except for the fact that I'm not into that but that's the only skillset I have. While anyone talented could easily do that too, but I can't the other way around. Caste systems are evil and that's exactly how genetics works.

body:
Here's just one, but there's tons of others: https://www.thegreatcoursesdaily.com/how-do-the-brains-of-men-and-women-differ/

Of course it tries to be PC and say the differences are a "myth" even though it literally shows how different they are. And that yes, men don't have or use as much of a brain, because for their traditional role in society they don't need to. Areas of the brain that control cognitive abilities are much larger in women. Men generally only use the left side of their brain, and do not have good connectivity with the right side but women do. So in a nutshell women have the right-brained abilities without any cost to the left brained ones, and on top of that the cognitive areas of their brains are larger and more prioritized than in men. Men can use the strategic functions they do have to come up with a way to do some things, but it still never beats having both areas and stronger cognitive abilities. Men's brains are optimized more to make quick decisions, clear out unnecessary information, not think or feel too much, and be able to provide, defend, and lead. This comes at an immense cost to other talents. Also worth noting is that children seem to all have a lot of brilliance in them, but during puberty the boys usually lose it whereas the girls do not (until they become obsessed with makeup and instagram that is, but that's an external factor and the ones who don't do that keep it). This cannot be explained by social factors, as people who do not care (like me) still lose it and are desperate to get it back. A lot of this is also down to genetics in general but I don't doubt that there's a sex component too.

Edit: yep, seems I was right about the puberty thing too. This one says the differences were not as prominent in children: https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2013/12/male-and-female-brains-really-are-built-differently/281962/

Looks like I had a taste of a gifted mind for a short time but I'm now screwed forever and ever.

body: I mean that far more men pursue things and develop their intelligence (at least on the left-brained side of things), while girls tend to think mostly about dress, makeup, instagram, gossip, etc. and also have less pressure to succeed because a man will likely provide for them anyway. Even if they do, for this reason they are less likely to go public about it and win awards and recognition and such, as they have less need to earn money from it. So you have to limit your sample to people who are equally invested in the same types of tasks. When you do that, the women almost always outperform the men the same way men crush them in athletics. And that is a completely rational conclusion. For an example, look at @sfrohne (cqtz/cqtz- on reddit), who posts almost entirely original content, including the stuff that looks like a team of professionals did it over time, she just did it herself real quick. And in almost every subject too. I never see men like this, even if they are damn good at something, it's still not god-level and usually not in more than a few different subjects, and takes a lot more time and effort for them to get to that level. But I've seen several women like this even though they're rare. For a direct comparison I have very similar interests as this person and even in places where I have 10x more experience than her she is light years ahead of me. The problem, I think, is guys mostly lack the intuition and creativity that is typical of girls, as they are the physical and leading type rather than the thinking and feeling ones. They can find a strategic method to try and imitate something and get close enough after a long time, but it still won't beat pure inborn abilities and extra brain functions (men actually do have smaller brains, especially on the right side, and can't even use many of the brain functions that women can) provided that the latter at all fosters it (which again, most girls don't in many areas, but when they do it's insane).
